caseStudy.content:
Year: 2025

What I did: UI/UX

Ongoing Project

Working in nonprofits, I regularly whished for a better way to share resources with people. Too often I found myself either putting together sheets of paper from an outdated binder or finding an online directory that was either way too intense, or way too basic. OpenResource is my solution to creating better resource directories.

caseBlocks.textBlock:
Problem Solved?

Platforms like findhelp already exist, but in my opinion, they run the risk of feeling too impersonal. I also know that most local governments and nonprofits often create their own lists. So what if, instead of relying on a single platform, these organizations could have a simple, unified way to keep doing what they’re doing… just better?

Solving it... My Own Way

Since this is not a problem with no solutions, it became a matter of taking whats already been done and making them better and more accessible for both users and organizations.

Simplification

A core principle of OpenResource (if not the core principle) is clarity, so I focused on stripping back the overwhelming amount of lists and replacing them with a clean search and filter flow. I coupled this with jargon free tags and consistent card layouts to make resources easy to scan.

Reflection

OpenResource has been my hardest project to scope, because it feels bigger than a single deliverable and could be executed in many different ways. So far, I’ve focused on making flows and systems that make clear and trustworthy directories which already feels like an improvement to the status quo. While in its current state it works as a single site, OpenResource is still in progress, with the goal to expand this out into a full design system that organizations can adapt to their own local directories.
